review.title: Artificial Intelligence and Data Science in the Automotive Industry
review.abstract: Data science and machine learning are the key technologies when it comes to the processes and products with automatic learning and optimization to be used in the automotive industry of the future. This article defines the terms "data science" (also referred to as "data analytics") and "machine learning" and how they are related. In addition, it defines the term "optimizing analytics" and illustrates the role of automatic optimization as a key technology in combination with data analytics. It also uses examples to explain the way that these technologies are currently being used in the automotive industry on the basis of the major subprocesses in the automotive value chain (development, procurement; logistics, production, marketing, sales and after-sales, connected customer). Since the industry is just starting to explore the broad range of potential uses for these technologies, visionary application examples are used to illustrate the revolutionary possibilities that they offer. Finally, the article demonstrates how these technologies can make the automotive industry more efficient and enhance its customer focus throughout all its operations and activities, extending from the product and its development process to the customers and their connection to the product.

sections.text: JOURNAL TITLE - MONTH YEAR 1 Data science and machine learning are the key technologies when it comes to the processes and products associated with automatic learning and optimization to be used in the automotive industry of the future. In this article, the terms "data science" (also referred to as "data analysis") and "machine learning" are defined and how they relate to each other. Furthermore, it defines the term "optimization of analytics" and illustrates the role of automatic optimization as a key technology in combination with data analysis. As the industry is only just beginning to explore the wide range of potential applications for these technologies, visionary examples of applications are used to illustrate the revolutionary possibilities they offer. Finally, the article shows how these technologies can make the automotive industry more efficient and customer-oriented, from product development to improving its overall product activities.

sections.text: Gartner uses the term "prescriptive analytics" to describe the highest level of the ability to make business decisions based on data-based analytics, illustrated by the question "What should I do?," and prescriptive analytics provides the necessary decision support when a person is still involved, or automation when that is no longer the case. Levels below that, in ascending order in terms of the use and usefulness of AI and data science, are defined as: descriptive analytics ("what happened?"), diagnostic analytics ("why did it happen?") and predictive analytics ("what will happen?"). The last two levels are based on data science technologies, including data mining and statistics, while descriptive analytics essentially uses traditional business intelligence concepts (Data Warehouse, OLAP). sections.text: An early definition of artificial intelligence by the IEEE Neural Networks Council was "the study of how to get computers to do things that people are doing better at the moment." 5 Although this is still true, current research also focuses on improving the way software does things that computers have always been better at, such as analyzing large amounts of data. Data is also the basis for the development of artificially intelligent software systems, not only to collect information, but also to: • learn, understand, and interpret information; • to behave adaptively; to plan; to draw conclusions; to solve problems; to think abstractly; to understand and interpret ideas and language.

sections.heading: 4.2 Procurement
sections.text: The procurement process uses a variety of data on suppliers, purchase prices, discounts, delivery reliability, hourly rates, raw material specifications and other variables. Consequently, the calculation of KPIs for the purpose of evaluating and ranking suppliers is no problem at all nowadays. Data mining methods make it possible to use the available data, for example, to generate forecasts, to identify key supplier characteristics with the greatest possible impact on performance criteria or to predict delivery reliability. In terms of optimizing analytics, the specific parameters that an automobile manufacturer can influence to achieve optimal conditions are also important. Overall, the Finance Division is a very good field for optimizing analytics, as the available data contains information on the most important success factors of the company. Continuous monitoring 34 is worth a brief mention here, in terms of controlling. This monitoring is based on financial and controlling data, which is 34, is used in many ways and is actually very general.

sections.heading: 4.3 Logistics
sections.text: In the field of logistics, a distinction can be made between procurement logistics, production logistics, distribution logistics and spare parts logistics. Procurement logistics takes into account the process chain that extends from the purchase of goods to the dispatch of the material to the receiving warehouse. When it comes to the purchase of goods, a large amount of historical price information is available for data mining purposes, which can be used to generate price forecasts and, in combination with supplier reliability data, to analyze supplier performance. As for suppliers, the optimization of suppliers can be used to identify and optimize the most important cost factors. A similar situation applies to production logistics, which deals with the planning, control and monitoring of internal transport, handling and warehouse processes. Depending on the granularity of the available data, it is possible to identify bottlenecks, optimize inventories and minimize the time needed, dealing with logistics, for example, logistics and monitoring.

sections.heading: 4.4 Production
sections.text: Each step of the production process will benefit from the consistent use of data mining. Therefore, it is essential that all production parameters are continuously recorded and stored. As the main objective of optimization is usually to improve quality or reduce the occurrence of defects, further optimization areas are required and it must be possible to assign these data to the process parameters. This approach can be used to achieve significant improvements, especially with regard to new production processes. Other optimization areas include energy consumption and the throughput of a production process per unit. Optimization of analyses can be performed both in terms of quality and application.

sections.heading: 4.7 Connected customer
sections.text: Although this term is not yet established as such, it describes a future in which both the customer and his vehicle are fully integrated into modern information technology, which is closely related to marketing and sales issues such as customer loyalty, personalised user interfaces, vehicle behaviour in general and other visionary aspects (see also Section 5). By connecting to the Internet and using intelligent algorithms, a vehicle can respond to spoken commands and search for answers that can, for example, communicate directly with the navigation system and change the destination. Communication between vehicles makes it possible to collect and exchange information on road and traffic conditions that is much more precise and up-to-to-date than those that can be accessed via central systems. An example is the formation of black ice, which is often very local and temporary and can be easily identified and communicated in the form of a warning to other vehicles today.

sections.heading: 5 Vision
sections.text: Vehicles are already being developed using "modular systems," which allow components to be used across multiple model series, while at the same time shortening development cycles. However, the field of virtual vehicle development has not yet seen any effective attempts to use machine learning methods to extract knowledge based on other historical knowledge to support future development projects and make them more efficient. This issue is closely interwoven with data management, the complexity of data mining in simulation and data optimization, and the difficulty of defining an adequate representation of knowledge related to vehicle development is constrained by the organizational constraints of the vehicle development process.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: Artificial intelligence has already found its way into our daily lives and is no longer just the subject of science fiction novels. Currently, AI is mainly used in the following areas: • Analytical data processing • Domains where qualified decisions must be made quickly on the basis of a large amount of (often heterogeneous) data • Monotonous activities that still require constant alerting. In the area of analytical data processing, in the coming years we will see the transition from the exclusive use of systems for additional use on our behalf. In the area of data analysis in particular, we are currently developing individual analytical solutions to specific problems, although these solutions cannot be used in different contexts.
